title: 103_hr358
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement Act." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress recognizes the risks law enforcement officers face daily, the lack of support from the Federal Government, their role in combating drugs and crime, the increase in violent crime and drug use, the need for a review of current issues, and the importance of studying law enforcement with Federal Government support. A comprehensive study of law enforcement issues, including the role of the Federal Government in supporting officers and responsibility for crime control, would help redefine relationships between the Federal Government, the public, and law enforcement officials. The "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement" is established to study law enforcement issues and redefine relationships between the Federal Government, the public, and law enforcement officials. The Commission will study and recommend changes regarding law enforcement agencies at all levels, including funding, employment conditions, information-sharing systems, research and training, equipment and resources, cooperation among agencies, government and agency responsibility in solving crime, and the impact of the criminal justice system. The Commission will consult with law enforcement officers, local officials, and community leaders nationwide to gather information and advice on important law enforcement issues, including the impact of the criminal justice system. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 25 members, including individuals from national law enforcement organizations representing officers and management. Appointments are made by various leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. Members include individuals with academic expertise in law enforcement, Members of the House and Senate, and a Federal law enforcement representative from the Department of the Treasury. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. Members include individuals with academic expertise in law enforcement, Members of the House and Senate, and representatives from Federal law enforcement agencies. The Comptroller General serves in an advisory capacity overseeing the methodology of the Commission's study, and the members select a chairperson from among themselves. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House of Representatives, Senate, and the President. Members select a chairperson from among themselves. Members receive no additional pay but travel expenses. Appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission may procure temporary services from experts and consultants under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services as requested by the Commission. The Commission also has powers outlined in Section 7. The Commission, under Section 7, has the power to hold hearings, receive evidence, delegate authority, obtain information from federal agencies, accept gifts, and use the United States mails. Additionally, the Commission can procure temporary services from experts, receive assistance from federal agencies, and request administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission will submit a report to Congress with legislative proposals within eighteen months of its appointment. It will cease to exist sixty days after submitting the report. Two specific titles from previous acts will be repealed.
